texts.definition: Game actions that point players towards important aspects of game worlds, or entities within them.
markups: <style="Definition">Game actions that point players towards important aspects of game worlds, or entities within them.</style>

Navigating in game world can be difficult depending on their complexity and the skills of the players. <style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style> is a way of supporting players by letting them easily know which direction they should be moving or directing their attention.

Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mirror's%20Edge">Mirror's Edge</link></style> can by a simple button press know which direction to move since this gameplay action turns their avatar in the direction of the level exit. Crafting a compass in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> allows players to know the direction to their spawn points, which can help navigation in the immense game worlds generated by the game.

Letting players aim correctly of enemies by a single button press is a form of <style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicator</style>. Examples of games with this include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Batman:%20Arkham%20Asylum">Batman: Arkham Asylum</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mass%20Effect%20series">Mass Effect series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tomb%20Raider%20series">Tomb Raider series</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style> can be used with all different types of ways of presenting <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, i.e. <style="Link"><link="first-person-views">First-Person</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="third-person-views">Third-Person</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="god-views">God Views</link></style>. They are either provided by game systems simply by moving the perspective of players to the interesting point, typically by manipulating <style="Link"><link="cameras">Cameras</link></style>, or by presenting it through some part of the game interface, e.g. through <style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style> or compasses. <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> are sometimes used to do <style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style>, e.g. pointing out <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> when players are about to enter <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> with them.

Many places in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> may qualify to have <style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style>, <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style> are specific ones related to goals (or sequences of goals). Although they may change view points, <style="Link"><link="killcams">Killcams</link></style> are specific <style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style> for spots where kills have just occurred while <style="Link"><link="picture-picture-views">Picture-in-Picture Views</link></style> can be used to point out any game world place or event without removing the current view. <style="Link"><link="auto-aim">Auto-Aim</link></style> support is a way of providing <style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style> on <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style> more generally can trigger on gameplay context to give players' <style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style> is both an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Information%20Patterns">Information</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Interface%20Patterns">Interface Pattern</link></style>.

Besides helping in <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style> can draw players' attention to <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>. While this can make games more <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual</link></style>, it can also be detrimental to player learning (see Linderoth 2010<ref name="Linderoth"/>) because it makes players not need to engage in  <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style>.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style> can represent perceptual abilities of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> in games with <style="Link"><link="first-person-views">First-Person Views</link></style>, the pattern can imply such as well as <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Point of Interest Indicators</style> that are initiated by game systems rather than players are likely to cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style>.
